article.headline: Broadway wonât reopen until June 2021 because of the pandemic â 3 reasons why theaters will be closed for so long
article.body: Theater fans wonât be able to give their regards to Broadway in person until June 2021 at the earliest. And certain factors could prevent New York Cityâs theaters from reopening for quite some time. The Broadway League, the trade group that represents theater owners and producers, announced Friday that Broadway performances would be canceled through May 30, 2021 because of the coronavirus outbreak. Theaters are offering exchanges and refunds for tickets purchased for performances through then. The closure of Broadway, which began in March, led producers to pull the plug on some productions. Disney DIS, +1.53% Â said in May that it would close its Broadway musical production of âFrozenâ because of the pandemic. Previously, producers said the curtain had fallen for good on the productions of two plays, âHangmenâ and âWhoâs Afraid of Virginia Woolf?â When the Broadway League previously announced that the Great White Way would remain closed through Labor Day, Charlotte St. Martin, the organizationâs president, told MarketWatch that there was a significant chance performance cancellations would be extended further. Thatâs because the arts and entertainment industry was in the fourth phase of New York stateâs official reopening plan, which calls for gradually putting certain business sectors back online as long as the state meets certain metrics. âWe literally cannot reopen unless there is a confidence in the safety of the cast and crew and theatergoers,â St. Martin told MarketWatch in May. âSo we donât really know when that will be and thatâs part of the challenge weâre facing.â There are three big challenges facing Broadway shows in the age of coronavirus that could hamper its chances at reopening: No. 1: Nearly 16% of Broadway theatergoers are over the age of 65. And once you remove tourists from the equation, that percentage goes higher, industry experts said. No. 2: During the 2018-2019 season, tourists from outside the New York metropolitan area purchased 65% of the tickets sold for Broadway shows, according to data from the Broadway League, and nearly one in five Broadway audience members was visiting from abroad. No. 3: Many of the theaters are over 100 years old, and feature narrow aisles, seats arranged very close together and tiny bathrooms. Audience sizes would need to be reduced significantly to adhere to health expertsâ guidelines to keep people at least six feet away from each other. Social distancing isnât possible in most Broadway theaters, St. Martin added. “ âSocial distancing just doesnât allow a show to be viable financially.â ” â Charlotte St. Martin, president of the Broadway League Backstage, actors and crew members are often in extremely close quarters, which makes the risk of transmitting an airborne illness like the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 much higher. âSocial distancing just doesnât allow a show to be viable financially,â St. Martin said. But even setting aside the troublesome logistics of reopening, there are other factors that will limit Broadwayâs ability to bounce back from the coronavirus pandemic.Tourists are a key part of Broadwayâs audience Read more:Letter from New York, epicenter of coronavirus: âThe streets are virtually empty, but the birds go on singingâ With such a large share of the audience for a Broadway show on any given day being made up of out-of-town visitors, Broadwayâs ability to bounce back will very much depend on New York Cityâs tourism sectorâs ability to return to full strength. And if the past is any indication, that could take quite some time. âItâs a completely different world that weâre in now versus 9/11,â said Gregg Arst, president of theatrical ticketing analytics and consulting firm Tanna. âBut the example there is that it took about four years for international tourism to get back up to pre-9/11 levels.â “ Tourists purchased 65% of the tickets sold for Broadway shows last season. ” As a result, if Broadway reopens before tourism in New York has rebounded, producers are going to look to fill the seats at their shows with audience members from New York and its suburbs. That pivot could pose some difficulty for longer-running shows like âWickedâ and âChicago.â New York audiences are already familiar with those shows, which could make them a tougher sell. âThe freshness of a new Broadway show has its own enticement,â he said. âThe new shows may have an easier time going after the local audiences but the older legacy shows may be able to use this moment to really reinvigorate New York and the fabric of Broadway as part of their lives.âBroadwayâs local audience tends to skew older Itâs not really the case that when you look out at a Broadway audience you see a sea of grey hair. While there is a perception that Broadway theatergoers skew older, St. Martin said, the reality is that the average age of an audience member was 42.3 last season. âItâs not spring chickens, but itâs not the older audience,â St. Martin said. âYou take away all the tourists, whatâs left? The Manhattan audiences tend to skew even older,â said Bill Hofstetter, a New York-based theater marketer. “ Almost 16% of Broadway theatergoers are over the age of 65 ” Older people are particularly susceptible to life-threatening complications from COVID-19. As a result, many older theatergoers feel more trepidation about returning to the seats of the Great White Way. A May study of New York City theatergoers conducted by Shugoll Research, a Maryland-based marketing research firm, found that 23% of people 55 and older said they were very unlikely to return to the theater. Another 45% said they would wait six months or longer before seeing shows again. Only 21% said they were very likely to start seeing shows again in the coming season. âWould you let your father go into a theater?â Hofstetter said. While older audience members are an important part of the theatergoing community, St. Martin noted that the industryâs calculations on when to reopen wouldnât be based on any one group. âOur audience has to be safe no matter what age they are,â she said. Donât miss: âOpening up does not mean social activitiesâ: Your coronavirus guide to safely commuting, shopping, traveling and visiting the doctor as states reopenHow Broadway bounces back New York is highly dependent on Broadway reopening in order to thrive in a post-coronavirus world. In its last season, Broadway contributed $14.7 billion worth of economic impact to the Big Apple. âThatâs people who stay in the hotels and eat in the restaurant because theyâre here to see a Broadway show,â St. Martin said. Right. âBroadway is often called the beating heart of New York City, but it also provides real jobs that deliver real benefit to not just the Times Square area, but to the entire city.â In previous times of hardship the city has lent a hand â following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, the city subsidized the purchase of tens of thousands of tickets to Broadway shows. But as St. Martin noted, that âdoesnât even fill a house in one night.â And that relief would only come after the city has dealt with more pressing priorities. “ âBroadway is often called the beating heart of New York City, but it also provides real jobs that deliver real benefit to not just the Time Square area, but to the entire city.â ” â Charlotte St. Martin, president of the Broadway League Broadway, in the meantime, could borrow from the approach airlines have taken as they grapple with waves of cancellations because of the coronavirus, Arst said. âAirlines are looking out a year in advance,â he said. Most airlines are providing travelers with vouchers rather than cash refunds if they proactively cancel their travel plans because of COVID-19. Broadway could take a similar approach and try to entice people to exchange their tickets for next summer rather than cancel. âThatâs not to say the customer is not just going to want their money back because there are customers who need that economic relief as well,â Arst noted. Beyond Broadway, regional theaters, touring shows and off-Broadway productions could have an easier time reopening, Hofstetter added. And theatergoers can expect to see discounts when shows return, industry experts said, though these could be limited depending on how many people shows can seat. Whatever route Broadway producers and theater owners choose, this historical closure will be challenging to bounce back from. âItâs certainly sobering to know New York will be without Broadway this summer,â Arst said.
